channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-3014] ZapfDingbats not finding a substitute in Windows 8.1 Pro
item.description:
When running PDFBox on Windows 8.1 Pro, it can't find a proper substitute for ZapfDingbats.

This email chain from the mailing list talks about this problem but the fix doesn't work for me:
http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/pdfbox-users/201504.mbox/%3CA8C49658-B378-4294-BAA5-470EF822F077@jahewson.com%3E

I was able to fix this problem by adding "MS-PGothic" to the substitutes Array for ZapfDingbats (FontMapperImpl.java).
item.summary: ZapfDingbats not finding a substitute in Windows 8.1 Pro

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
According to this website, MS Gothic is available in W8:
https://www.microsoft.com/typography/fonts/product.aspx?PID=164

Please run this code, what do you get as output?

        File ttcFile = new File("c:/windows/fonts/msgothic.ttc");
        TrueTypeCollection trueTypeCollection = new TrueTypeCollection(ttcFile);
        System.out.println(trueTypeCollection.getFonts());

The results from the code are:

[MS-Gothic, MS-UIGothic, MS-PGothic]

LOG.debug("try " + format + " substitute " + substituteName + " for " + postScriptName);

When it then converts that file into a byte[], then a ByteArrayInputStream, then an ObjectInputStream, and then calls readObject() the object returned looks like this:

MS-PGothic (TTF, mac: 0x0, os/2: 0x801, cid: null) C:\windows\FONTS\msgothic.ttc

So MS-PGothic is set in the cachedInfos List which is then used to populate the fontInfoList.

The below are used to setProvider in the FontMapperImpl class, which are used to set the map fontInfoByName. When the getFont method is called in the FontMapperImpl class, it tries to get the FontInfo by looking up the postscriptName in the fontInfoByName map. Since the msgothic.ttc was set to MS-PGothic in the map, it can not find the font in the map because it is searching for MS-Gothic. It then returns null and does not make the substitution.

I wrote a stand alone java app and it fails every time. Here is the code:

    public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException {
        PDDocument document = PDDocument.load(new File("PATH_TO_FILE\\az101-1.15.0.pdf"));
        document.getDocumentCatalog().getAcroForm().flatten();
        PDFRenderer rend = new PDFRenderer(document);
        BufferedImage img = rend.renderImageWithDPI(0, 175);
    }

When I debug the FontMapperImpl class in the getFont method, the line:

 FontInfo info = fontInfoByName(postScriptName);

always sets info equal to null when postScriptName is "MS-Gothic" for the same reasons as in my previous post.
I will attach the pdf I used to run this code.
Attached the pdf that fails to render check marks when flattened and using PdfRenderer to render a BufferedImage.

I think I came closer to the problem. The cache uses the filename as key. So for ttc files, there will be only one font info assigned to a key.

The problem doesn't happen on my computer, because for some unknown reason, not all font infos are saved into the cache, or some is lost before reloading.

Please try this, to verify my theory: change saveCache() like this:

            for (FSFontInfo fontInfo : fontInfoList)
            {
                if (fontInfo.file.getAbsolutePath().endsWith(".ttc"))
                {
                    // remove .ttc files from older versions
                    prefs.remove(fontInfo.file.getAbsolutePath());
                    continue;
                }

If my theory is correct, it should work properly after the second run.
That appears to have fixed it! I can't reproduce the problem with the webapp or with the standalone app. Thanks!

I updated for the first time since this was fixed and this appears to be broken again. The same thing is happening even though your fix is still there. Standalone app breaks as well.

On a side note, I started playing with Amazon EC2 and their standard Amazon Linux server only contains one font, Dejavu. Do you know where I could get a font to substitute?
Could you try again by reverting to a previous version of FileSystemFontProvider.java?
re your other question, search on old backups or google for a file named "ZD______.PFB" (as long as you only test for yourself). Or buy the file from Adobe, I think the price is about $40.

After those changes the cache doesn't survive any restart anymore and is rebuilt every time a new application is started.

I know those changes were made for a good reason but now the loadCache method finds "new" fonts (all non cached ttc files) on every startup again and again which leads to a rebuild of the whole cache. Either we have to find a way to cache ttc as well or we have to implement a mechanism to add those new fonts instead if rereading all fonts.

WDYT?

I had thought that the cache would only load newly found fonts. Anyway, ttc file info MUST be cached with all its fonts. I assume this will be done as part of the intended cache rewrite; if not, then I'll do it after the cache rewrite has been done.

I believe this was my fault. After reverting to an earlier version, and it working, and then updating to current version, and debugging all the way through, it still worked. I believe something was messed up in my build and/or my workspace. Sorry about the confusion.
This is something I intend to address in PDFBOX-3001. Don't forget that the "old" font files on disk could change too.
In case anyone else is dealing with an Amazon Linux server, I was able to add DejaVuSans (included font with Amazon Linux server) to the substitute array for ZapfDingbats to get everything working.
